reviewText: What might have been just another exploitative man vs. nature film, the theme from "Jaws" playing in the background, is, instead, a dire reminder of fate and chance when dealing with unpredictable elements. A young couple, Daniel and Suzanne, exhibit the usual tensions of a relationship the night before a scheduled dive trip from an unnamed island, but are delighted to explore the depths of the ocean with the others on a chartered dive boat. When the dive times out, a busy attendant miscounts the returning divers and the couple, Daniel and Suzanne, resurface to find that they are alone in the water with no boat in sight. Only gradually coming to terms with the seriousness of their dilemma, the couple spends the first few hours frantically waving at distant boats on the horizon to no avail, finally resorting to word games until even that effort exhausts them.Eventually, the seriousness of their situation unavoidable, Suzanne and Daniel admit that their only hope lies in the dive boat returning, assuming they are noted as missing before the boat returns to shore. In reality, the boat has docked, the weary divers refreshed and enjoying island night life. It isn't until the following morning that the couple's dive gear is discovered and a search begun in earnest. Meanwhile, the hapless couple goes through the various stages one would expect in such circumstances, denial, rage, fear, grief, acceptance, at times terrified, then desperately clinging to one another for comfort. This is the predator's playground, the couple intruders, or, at best, fodder for the sea. The climax is striking, the tightening circle of sharks, the shocked faces of the helpless divers, the drone of the boats and search helicopters, the flashing fins, the quiet lapping of the waves, the end. Luan Gaines/2006.

reviewText: Synopsis: Workaholic twenty-somethings Susan and Daniel take a break from their hectic lives to vacation in the tropics, where they embark on a fateful scuba diving trip. After a half hour or so of pleasant underwater exploration, they break the surface to find that the dive charter boat has accidentally left them behind. Suddenly alone many miles from land, with sharks and nightfall closing in, the two cling to one another and hope to survive until someone notices their absence and comes back for them.I sure am glad I didn't have to write the script for Open Water. (Not that anyone was lining up to ask me.) You've got to be awfully creative, I think, to take a couple of actors, let 'em bob around in salt water for a while, and make a movie out of it. Not that it's Doctor Zhivago, of course - it's only 79 minutes long - but still. There are only so many possibilities you can explore involving angst, scuba gear, and sea fauna before you run out of either plot or players. And since you're making a suspense movie rather than, say, My Seafood Dinner With Andre, it's not like you can get too cerebral with the dialogue:"Was that a fin?""Where?""Something just brushed past my leg!""We're all alone and in danger and really, really wet. Darn that stupid dive boat!""This is all your fault! [Pause.] Was that another fin? Something else just bumped my leg!"And that, in a seashell, is the problem with Open Water. It's limited. Two not-very-interesting people whine, hope, commiserate, speculate, recriminate, and occasionally get nibbled on while a growing congregation of predators decide whether they've got a craving for neoprene. After the dive boat leaves the protagonists stranded, the film boils down to a single issue: will they be eaten by sharks, or not? And while that might sound like an interesting question, is really isn't. Because it doesn't matter what our heroes do - whether they swim or whether they drift, whether they're brave, cowardly, noble, spiteful, or what have you - the outcome is out of their hands. Like us, they've got nothing to do but wait.Contrast that with the classic of the genre: Jaws. The draw for that movie was, of course, a really really big shark. But what made the movie great had little to do with the fish and everything to do with the humans involved - how they took their lives in their own hands and risked them for their own compelling purposes.If Susan and Daniel from Open Water were vacationing on Amity Island at the time of the Jaws attacks, one can't imagine them deciding to accompany Chief Brody and Hooper and Quint on the Orca for their appointment with destiny. The young couple would no doubt have remained sensibly on the beach, working their cell phones and grumbling that they should've gone to St. Moritz instead.As it is, they're just a couple of yuppy schlubs who miss a travel connection and end up as live bait. What's cool about that?

reviewText: "Open Water" plays like somebody's bad vacation video from the eighties, but it's no joke: Tom and Eileen Lonergan were a real life couple left behind in 1998 by the Outer Edge Dive Company during a scuba dive on the Great Barrier Reef.  If you're not a fan of diving, sharks, or water, "Open Water" isn't going to change your mind.Daniel Kintner (Daniel Travis) and Susan Watkins (Blanchard Ryan) have decided to take a vacation to get away from their highly stressful day jobs. When out on their dive, they separate and the crew fails to accurately take a headcount due to one diver who forgot his equipment. When Daniel and Susan surface, they belatedly realize that nobody is coming back for them.That's it. That's the whole film.  Two people, with footage taken by a grainy camera, who can do nothing but float in the wide ocean.  Occasionally they dive below to see more. But other than those desperate forays, this is a stage play that takes place between two people on open water.  They go through the five stages of grief: Denying they've been forgotten, angry at each other for going on the trip, reconciling, giving up hope, and then finally accepting their fate.  Helping them along the way are fish, jellyfish, and sharks.  Lots and lots of sharks.Because "Open Water" is based on true events, there's no happy ending and barely a plot.  It's just two people in a beautiful vacation destination in open sight of ship that can't see them, abandoned by a support structure they took for granted.There's one point the film left out. Fishermen found a diver's slate that read:"[Mo]nday Jan 26; 1998 08am. To anyone [who] can help us: We have been abandoned on A[gin]court Reef by MV Outer Edge 25 Jan 98 3pm. Please help us [come] to rescue us before we die. Help!!!"This film will haunt your most beautiful beachside fantasies.

reviewText: I watched this movie with all the negative reviews (mostly from friends and co-workers) in mind hoping for something to like.  I was pleasantly surprised that this was a gem of a film that was made with not much money, but with a lot of heart and determination.If you watch the extra features you discover that they made this movie solely on week-ends and vacation time, all the while on a shoestring budget.  There were no stunt doubles (the actors were in the water with the sharks the whole time), no animatronic or CGI sharks (all the fish in the movie were abasolutely, 100% real), and the husband/wife team that made this movie did this almost entirely on their own with no huge studio backing them up, unitll Lion's Gate Films saw it at Sundance and bought it.  And, unlike many other movies set on the ocean, this was actually filmed in the real ocean...not some sound stage with an olympic-sized pool to safely film in.  In a nutshell, the place was real, the wildlife was real...this whole film was real.On the technical side of things, the sound is superb.  If you have a surround system at home, fire up the Dolby Digital 5.1 or DTS surround mode and watch it.  You will get an undeniably creepy closed in feeling when the cameras are sumberged and the water sounds like it is enveloping you in your own living room!!!!The video is very clear, being it was shot on digital cameras.  The underwater scenery is just beautiful. On the surface you can see every detail when the sharks surface and circle the two stranded divers.  About the only negative aspect to the video is it was shot documentary-style, but I didn't have that much of a problem with that once the movie really took off.If you haven't yet checked this movie out...please do.  If you have and didn't like it...I think it would be worth a second shot.  Just watch the "making of" featurette, you may just walk away with an appreciation for how much work, creativity, and passion went into this project.

reviewText: The only thing that might make this compact little movie more terrifying would be a musical score from John Williams.  Minus the signature "buh rump... buh rump" from the Jaws theme, this film is scary enough as it is.  Working with factual events as the basis for their story, filmmakers Chris Kentis and Laura Lau have put together a gripping scenario of a couple abandoned far out to sea by their scuba excursion.Stressed with careers and a relationship that's clearly moved past the honeymoon phase, Susan and Daniel are seriously in need of a vacation.  That's underscored by phone calls on the way to the airport, time spent with the laptop in the hotel room, and mild bickering sufficient enough to cast an occasional cloud over potentially romantic moments.  Their escape takes them to a small Caribbean island where they begin to decompress with the standard sun, sand and libation.  But that relaxation reverses when they surface from a scuba diving excursion to discover that their boat is nowhere to be seen.  The drama from that point forward is as real as it gets, even down to the panic-fed arguments; one of which ends with the line "I wanted to skiing...!"Forget mechanical sharks and CGI animated sea creatures, Open Water was filmed at sea with real threats - courtesy of a "shark wrangler."  Only 79 minutes in length, the film steadily builds the tension to the very end.  Blanchard Ryan (Susan) and Daniel Travis (Daniel) deserve praise for even agreeing to act under the circumstances in which they were placed, and they deliver solid, believable performances.Open Water won't appeal to everyone.  It was filmed on a shoestring budget, on digital video, with unknown actors; there is a scene with nudity that might offend some, and opinions regarding the ending seem to be split 50/50 between "great" and "terrible".  If any of that bothers you, then consider something else for your viewing enjoyment.I'm not normally a "DVD extras" kind of guy, but the interviews with Chris Kentis and Laura Lau, along with the commentary of the actors provide ample reason to choose this format over VHS.  Are you at all curious about how you protect a cameraman surrounded by a school of sharks?  And how do you get sharks to perform for the camera anyway?One footnote, Kentis and Lau were at a Thai seaside resort when the horrendous tsunami hit.  Fortunately, they managed to escape relatively unscathed.  I wonder if the experience might influence their next film project.

reviewText: "Open Water" is 2004's "no budget" wonder by the husband and wife filmmaking team of Chris Kentis and Laura Lau, who made the film over a period of 2 1/2 years on weekends and holidays for about $120,000. Handheld digital video is well-suited to this tale of terror at sea -where everything bobs up and down anyway, so the film doesn't suffer much for its limited budget. If watching water makes you queasy, "Open Water" is not for you, but otherwise this is an effective reality-based film that exploits human impotence in the face of nature's power to tell a story of terror and regret.Susan (Blanchard Ryan) and Daniel (Daniel Travis) are a couple hoping to revive their strained marriage with a tropical vacation. While on a scuba-diving expedition, confusion in the head count causes their tour boat to leave without them, stranding the couple miles out at sea. Harassed by sharks and other sea creatures, the couple contend with their fears and with each other while hoping they will be rescued.Two people floating in the ocean for a hour is surprisingly watchable. Every time it begins to get tedious, the monotony is punctuated by some sort of action or change. There are several scenes of real suspense, and the two actors are able to keep us interested in the characters with only water, sharks, and silence to help them. I give Blanchard Ryan and Daniel Travis a lot of credit. They not only spent more than 120 hours in the water, a couple of days of it with 40-50 live, hungry sharks, but they are the film's sole focus, and these two unknown actors succeed in carrying it. Chris Kentis and Laura Lau deserve much praise, as well. Kentis wrote, directed, and, crucially, edited "Open Water" very well. Lau produced. And they both filmed. Two actors. Two camerapeople. That was the entire ensemble. No crew except a boat captain, Lau's sister, and a shark wrangler for 2 days. The wonders of digital video."Open Water" claims to be "based on true events". Inspired by real events would be more accurate. There  is no shortage of tales of scuba divers being accidentally abandoned miles off shore by their boats. But, if you are interested, the case that inspired "Open Water" is probably a 1998 incident in which American tourists Tom and Eileen Lonergan were left at the Great Barrier Reef off the coast of Australia while on a scuba-diving excursion. There is no reason to think they had trouble with sharks, though. "Open Water" is a different story under similar circumstances. But knowing the Lonergans' story before viewing the film would spoil some surprises.The DVD: Bonus features include 2 featurettes, 2 audio commentaries, a theatrical trailer, 7 deleted scenes, and a little bonus footage. In "The Indie Essentials: A Filmmaker's Guide to Gearing Up for a Marketable Movie" (5 minutes), 3 representatives of Lion's Gate, director Chris Kentis and producer Laura Lau talk about the characteristics of successful indie films. "Calm Beneath the Storm: The Making of Open Water" includes interviews with Kentis, Lau, and actors Blanchard Ryan and Daniel Travis. Director and producer take us from figuring out what equipment they would need, though filming and up to their collaboration with Lion's Gate, which acquired "Open Water" at the Sundance Film Festival. One audio commentary is by actors Blanchard Ryan and Daniel Travis, who discuss their characters, the movie's themes, filming, and swimming with sharks. The other audio commentary is by director Chris Kentis and wife, producer Laura Lau. They talk about shooting with no crew, the story, and how they got those shark shots. Both commentaries are interesting and provide insight into inspired independent filmmaking. Subtitles are available for the film in English and in Spanish.

reviewText: Open Water is a thriller, but not in the usual sense.  This thriller develops slowly and there is not one specific climax, which allows you to believe this is really happening.  The thrill comes not from gory violence, but from the suspense of not knowing what is happening around you, and being powerless to change that fact.  The thrill in this case is also accentuated by the dread of slowly succumbing to death alone.This film has been compared to other faux-documentaries like the Blair Witch Project, but it is different in at least one important way.  The person holding the camera is not one of the screen characters.  The camera is a silent observer, tagging along to record the events as they unfold in real time.  This is important to remember during the brief bedroom scene.  The main characters are lying there unclothed, and at first it seems like a case of gratuitous nudity.  But then you remember these are two people on a romantic vacation, relaxing in the privacy of their own room.  During the ocean scenes, it almost feels like one of the lurking sharks has the camera strapped to its back.The conclusion is unexpected and uncertain.  There is very little dialogue at this point, and the viewer is left to wonder what exactly the characters are thinking.  It is not an uplifting experience, but it is an introspective one.

reviewText: My brother hated this movie when he watched it at the theater.  He warned me not to bother spending any good movie on it, so I waited for its DVD release.  When I told him I had finally watched it, he just smiled at me and said, "did you like it? ... my favorite part is when they are floating on the water!".  I couldn't help but laugh... that pretty much describes it.I read the review below with the checklist.  Although it is a helpful guide, you should be aware that you can check all these and still come out not liking (or positively hating) the film.  I must say when I rented it, I was fully aware of what it was about.  I knew it was filmed in a grainy, documentary-style fashion.  I knew it has unknown actors for added cred.  I knew that the sharks where real.  I knew some of the hardships in filming it.  Most importantly, I knew that for a good 50 minutes or so, I would be looking at two people floating on the water.  This did not bother me.  In the end, what was dissapointing, and what I did NOT expect, was how little I cared by the end.I had been lead to believe by some of my friends (and by critics in many publications) that the drama in the movie was not entirely derived from the sharks, but that much of it depended on the complex interaction between the couple.  I was expecting a more meaningful exploration of male/female relationships than what I got.  To be honest, the human drama in the film was rather flat.  At no point was I really drawn in by the couple in the film... not by their pillow talk, not by their bickering over vacation plans, and ultimately not by their tragedy.  By the end, I simply did not care what happened to them.  The acting was bland, the dialogue was not intelligent, and the characters were not likeable (or even interesing).  When you have a film that consists of two characters floating in the ocean for almost 50 minutes, you should have all these elements present in order to keep the audieced tuned in.I did not hate the film as much as my brother did, but I certainly would not recommend it.  Sure, there are some genuinely frightful moments when the sharks attack, and the sequence at night is also somewhat disturbing.  But, for the most part, the film fails.  It did not deliver the emotional debt I would have expected.  It was an interesting concept, but one that ultimately lacked good excecution.

reviewText: This film gets featured at Sundance, a glowing review in The New Yorker, and two thumbs up from Ebert and Roper. So why it's overwhelmingly trashed on Amazon is a mystery.  Open Water is an exceptionally well-done low-budget indie starring unknowns and real scary sea creatures.  The creepy and unusual soundtrack is the perfect accompanyment.What was intended to be a stress-relieving trip to the Caribbean quickly turns into a young couple's worst nightmare when their dive boat leaves them stranded in open water. I had recently returned from the Bahamas on an identical trip when I saw this film.  There I learned this scenario of a dive boat taking off without someone, based on the true story of Tom and Eileen Lonergan, happens in real life more than you want to know, adding a horrifying layer of reality. The tourist industry does a good job of keeping this quiet.  It's easy to see how the head count can be screwed up on a crowded boat of strangers, bodies in constant motion, in and out of gear and in and out of the water.In his 2004 review of the film, "A Mystery Resurfaces," critic Daniel Foggo writes:  "It is chillingly authentic; all the more so because the lead actors, the relatively unknown Blanchard Ryan and Daniel Travis, spent more than 120 hours in the water 50 kilometres off Barbados amid all kinds of sea life, including the real bull sharks and grey reef sharks used in the scenes. Wearing chain mail under their wetsuits, the actors bobbed in the water while shark experts and the filmmakers manipulated their co-stars' movements by throwing chunks of bloody tuna near them."The incessant waves filmed at eye-level is exactly what it looks like in open water miles from shore, emphasizing how impossible it is to keep your head entirely above surface even in calm seas. It's hard to tell from a quick glance at a dorsal fin whether it is a dolphin or a shark coming at you. Just dangling there even for a short while can be unnerving when there are plenty of sharks around and something keeps brushing your legs. Yech. This couple is left to drift in the ocean all day and all night, and through a thunderstorm, sharks circling.  The ending is poignant, unexpected, and memorable.  Makes for truly terrifying entertainment.

reviewText: This film takes your breath away. It is not easy to watch. Great acting of the two main actors, who carry this film on their shoulders for more than an hour, mostly in cold waters, where all you can see is the shadow of sharks. The music keeps you on your toes. I found myself praying for their salvation. What a stupid way to ruin your life.This one is for people with a strong stomach. An untraditional Hollywood movie.Following this disturbing film, I contacted a friend diver, wondering whether the mistake that brought about this tragedy can happen in real life.In 1998, Tom and Eileen Lonergan disappeared off the Great Barrier Reef after a diving company accidentally left them behind in shark-infested waters. Their bodies were never found.They were planning to travel round the world before heading home, but first the couple were determined to visit the Barrier Reef. In Port Douglas, an upmarket diving and sailing town towards the end of the road north through Queensland, they decided to take a day trip on a 26-passenger boat, the Outer Edge. For A$160, the five crew would take them for three dives on the ribbon reefs, a stack of broad shoals that run along the seaward ramparts of the Barrier Reef, 40 miles offshore. On their third dive, round about 3pm, they headed off together and were last spotted swimming calmly 12m down. When they came to the surface after less than an hour underwater, the Outer Edge had gone.Being left behind on a dive is not an instant death sentence. Paul Lucas, a tourist from Leicester with less than 10 dives under his belt, survived for 40 hours in stormy seas in January 2000, after he was left behind by a dive boat in northern New South Wales. A diver is wearing an inflatable lifejacket and has the air to inflate it in a tank strapped to their back. The danger in the blazing heat of tropical Queensland is that, without fresh water, someone floating in the middle of the ocean may dehydrate long before help can arrive.The day after the incident the Outer Edge brought another tour party to the area, and one diver found six dive weights resting on the bottom. Oblivious to what had happened the previous day, a crew member described the find as a bonus.Inflatable dive jackets marked with Tom and Eileen's names were later washed ashore north of Port Douglas, along with their tanks - still buoyed up by a few remnants of air - and one of Eileen's fins. None showed any signs of the damage you would expect from a violent end, suggesting that the couple were not the victim of a shark attack, as the film suggests. Experts at the inquest speculated that, drifting helplessly back and forth on the tides in the building heat of the tropical sun, the couple may have been driven delirious by dehydration and have voluntarily struggled out of their cumbersome outfits. Without the buoyancy provided by their dive jackets and wetsuits, they would not have been able to tread water for long.The industry's damage-control mechanism was desperate and unpleasant. Rumours started spreading - many of them put about by the Outer Edge's owner, Tom Colrain - that there was more to the Lonergans' case than met the eye. Melancholy passages in the diaries of Tom and Eileen were raised as evidence that they had committed suicide, that he had killed her in a murder-suicide, even that they had faked their own deaths and sped off to a new life in another boat supposedly spotted nearby. Sightings of the Lonergans began pouring in from all over Australia.

reviewText: "Open Water" was filmed by a husband and wife team using hand-held digital cameras. Several reviewers here mentioned the "Blair Witch Project" and the WAY it was shot (cinematography). "Open Water" was shot in the same "B-Movie" vein. No soundtrack to speak of. No quality sound or even sound effects to speak of. Grainy images at times when the camera scrolls anywhere, as well as a somewhat bouncy camera from one scene to the next. The dialogue was hard to hear due to ocean water splashing and big rooms prone to echo. No big star names (not even small star names). Main characters Blanch Ryan and Dan Travis have all ready faded from sight. Eight (8) total cast members listed in the credits. 81 minutes long - and that includes the credits. Sure, "Open Water" relies on the primal fear that any human would have - being lost at sea (literally) and exposed (literally) to the harsh elements above and below the water. A "fact based exercise"? Once the boat leaves in the first 1/3 of the movie, it's all up to the director as to what happens... for the 2 were never found and no one really knows what became of them. A few scenes will make you jump when a shark surfaces and splashes about. There's no blood and guts that you might expect from a shark-type thriller. Some of the extras were minimally interesting in how they got the sharks to flurry back and forth in front of the actors (throwing food to the left, pause, then more food to the right). Ebert & Roeper gave it "2 thumbs up"... spare me! How long can you watch 2 people tread water? Worth seeing once - I guess so. Replay value - None. Worth buying? Um, no.

reviewText: Open Water (Chris Kentis, 2003)I did NOT see that ending coming.Chris Kentis' second feature film, made for a shoestring, ended up making just over thirty million in the theaters. A drop in the bucket for a Hollywood blockbuster, but thirty million for an indie flick about a couple of people stuck in the water? That's a smash hit, baby.Allegedly based on the true story of Tom and Eileen Lonergan, Open Water follows Susan Watkins (the gorgeous Blanchard Ryan, last seen in the execrable Super Troopers in a minor role) and her boyfriend Daniel Kintner (Daniel Travis, in his first screen appearance) as they take a vacation. Woo! Fun stuff. (The completely gratuitous nudity was probably meant to keep the audience interested before we get to the stuff you saw in the trailer. It worked.) Susan and Daniel head out for some scuba diving, but surface to discover that the boat has left without them, and spend the next twenty-four hours drifting through shark-infested waters trying to stay alive. (They must be in the Bermuda Triangle, because relatively early in the ordeal, a boat comes toward them. We cut to another scene, and when we come back, that boat is gone, and no mention of it is ever made again. Huh?)Open Water was marketed as a suspense thriller. Put that out of your head. If you want a good two-person suspense thriller, hunt down a copy of Radha Bharadwaj's amazing film Closetland. Open Water has far more in common (after the two get to drifting, anyway) with My Dinner with Andre. You've got two people and a lot of nothing else. What else are they going to do but talk?This, ultimately, is the film's shortcoming. In an eighty-minute film, we get roughly fifty minutes of Travis and Ryan floating around in the deep blue. Ask yourself: when was the last time you saw an eighty-minute film on the big screen? (The last one I can recall off the top of my head that wasn't animated was 1980's Motel Hell.) Ninety minutes is pretty much the lower limit these days. And this premise, as so ably shown by My Dinner with Andre, Closetland, and a handful of other two-person flicks, can easily be done, and done well, for longer than eighty minutes (or, actually, fifty in this movie). We get one tantalizing taste of what might have been when the two fall to accusing one another about whose fault it is that they're in this mess, but the rest of the script for the lost-in-the-ocean sequence might be a grand total of two pages long. It seems to be more an excuse for some interesting, if not overly beautiful, footage of things swimming around under the water and lot of shots of the empty horizon. Again, these are things that can work, given the right cinematographer. Here, they're all right, but nothing you can't see on the Discovery Channel.I'm not, by any means, saying not to see this movie. It's definitely worth a look, especially for those few times (the ending stands out here, in a huge way) Kentis overcomes his seeming fear of letting the actors do something really interesting. And it works, on some sort of primal level, in ways that many films aimed at disturbing the viewer do not. Maybe it's just because we're all, pretty much, afraid of sharks. But do your best, when watching, to try not to think of what this movie could have been, for you'll end up depressed if you do. ***

reviewText: ***1/2Low-concept horror films have always worked better for me than high-concept ones - and you can't get much more low concept, or low-budget, than "Open Water,"  a movie made on a digital cam for the whopping cost of $300,000.  A cinematic tour de force, "Open Water" takes a very plausible event from everyday life and uses it to show us just how vulnerable we are to the forces of nature and the exigencies of fate, becoming, in the process, a taut, disturbing thriller that haunts you long after the movie is over.Susan and Daniel are a yuppie couple who take a vacation to get away from the stresses and strains of their high pressured, workaholic lives.  When they go on a scuba diving expedition, they are accidentally left behind by the incompetent staff members of the company they've hired to take them out.  Cast adrift among schools of hungry sharks, Susan and Daniel can do little but float along helplessly, waiting for either salvation or doom to determine their fate.The movie has a rough-hewn look that separates it from the slick, plot-laden horror films made by mainstream studios.  The acting is also quite amateurish, although Blanchard Ryan and Daniel Travis seem to do a bit better while bobbing up and down in the water than while conversing on dry land.  In a lot of ways, though, the amateurism actually helps the movie seem more true-to-life and realistic.  Although the screenplay never spells the issues out explicitly, we sense that there's a strong undercurrent of troubled dissatisfaction running through the relationship.  This also adds to the human interest element of the story.Writer/director Chris Kentis resists the temptation to go over-the-top with elaborate special effects (which I'm sure he couldn't have afforded anyway) and contrived, in-the-nick-of-time rescues.  He allows the dread and nightmarish nature of the situation to insinuate itself into our bones and set our teeth on edge.  The suspense comes more from the anticipation of what might happen than from what actually does.  Of course, it helps that the sharks he shows us are real and not studio-manufactured facsimiles or the product of computer-generated graphics.This is the kind of homespun horror film, like "The Blair Witch Project," that winds up with as many detractors as defenders among the genre's diehard aficionados.  Indeed, if you prefer your thrillers on the high-tech, over-plotted side, then "Open Water" may not be for you.  But if you prefer a movie in which you can imagine yourself caught in the same predicament as its luckless characters, then "Open Water" may fill that need.
summary: preferable to most high budget horror films

reviewText: When an acquaintance of mine became a widow, she said she felt as if she were rowing out to sea in a canoe, getting farther and farther from shore. This movie recalled that feeling to my mind. Open Water could serve as a metaphor for the human condition in general. It evokes a sense of each individual's essential aloneness and fragility in an unknowable vastness. So I found it to be more poignant than all the sophisticated abstractions of Brecht and the host of existential playwrights. This movie achieves its incidental commentary on the human condition with an absolutely simple, realistic premise.The story is loosely based on fact. A couple was left behind in the water when their diving excursion cruise ship pulled anchor and sailed back to port without them. This movie brings home to viewers what it must have been like to be left in such deadly abandonment.Open Water first delivers a lesson against even the most seemingly small lack of consideration for others. The couple couldn't have been left behind except for the loutish actions of another husband and wife on the cruise. This latter twosome boarded the boat after their dive and were counted as being back on deck. Then they returned to the water and allowed themselves to be counted A SECOND TIME when they made their final return to the ship's deck. Viewers will gasp when they see this small, but oh-so-fateful thoughtlessness. The crew, thinking they had ticked off the same number of people returning to deck who had dived off the deck - chugged obliviously back to port.When our protagonist couple bobbed up from the depths, somewhat late for their rendezvous with the ship, they found themselves alone in the Caribbean, out of range of any vessel. They proceed to go through the same sequence of emotions that Elizabeth Kubler-Ross outlined as the stages a person goes through after receiving a grim medical diagnosis.First comes denial. The couple denies the seriousness of their situation. Then their blithe reassurances crumble and are replaced by bitter accusations. They flail out in anger against each other. "You should have..." "If only you hadn't..." And finally, they draw back together in loving resignation during what they finally recognize could be their last hours.I think almost everyone watching this movie will be touched by this couple's plight and will identify with the drowning isolation they face. You will remember this movie - when you face the loss of a loved one, when you face a crisis of your own, when you stare up at the stars at night or look out over the waves of the ocean - whenever you feel small and alone and lost.
summary: A Metaphor for the Human Condition

reviewText: "Open Water" sure appears to spark strong reactions!  The husband and wife team of Chris Kentis and Laura Lau did virtually everything on this movie except act, and if nothing else, their production strikes a chord - jangling or melodious - with people.This flick focuses on a yuppie couple, Susan (Blanchard Ryan) and Daniel (Daniel Travis), who escape their yuppie lives -- particularly Susan's cell phone -- for a quickie vacation to the islands.  But even tropical paradise isn't enough for these two - in one scene, we see them incredibly naked and incredibly attractive in bed, and they can't even muster up the gumption for a little rumpy-pumpy.  This scene underscores the whole unnerving mess that is about to follow.The next day, they go scuba diving and fail to get picked up by their boat.  Left to drift in the sea, they hit upon the core of the movie - for all our pretensions and modern-day conveniences, a human being is a very small creature on a very big planet, and two people aren't much bigger.  To paraphrase Rick Blaine, "The problems of two little people don't amount to a hill of beans in this world."  So true.Be advised - this is not a "shark movie" along the lines of "Jaws" or "Deep Blue Sea."  Sharks play a vitally important role, but as the often-unseen object of terror, not as the set up of horrifying big-budget spectacle a la Quint sliding into the shark's mouth in "Jaws."  Indeed, there are dozens of sharks in "Open Water," but they are reef sharks - there is nary a Great White or Tiger to be seen.This is the point of "Open Water" - a human being is not so significant that it takes the largest, meanest monster in the sea to take us out.  Instead, such forces as thirst, a stupid miscommunication, relatively small sharks, and a huge body of salt water are enough to drive us to terror and beyond.Made for a mere $130-odd thousand, "Open Water" is a no-frills movie.  David Mamet did not write the script - it goes for real-world truth rather than poetry or wit.  But as Susan and Daniel alternately complain, argue, love and support each other, you get the feeling that you really wouldn't be having a very different conversation if you were bobbing along at sea surrounded by a bunch of hungry little mouths.There are also virtually no clever camera tricks, but instead the movie uses camera angles and a few underwater shots to create a sense of foreboding and of genuine scares.  A late-night thunderstorm was enough to get the blood pumping!Long on gut reaction, short on virtually everything else, "Open Water" is a movie that makes you contemplate your place in the universe, and generally that contemplation isn't all that pleasant.  If you're looking for a big budget, jump-out-of-your-seat-at-set-pieces kind of picture, "Open Water" isn't for you.  If you want some spooky moments, genuine tension, and admire economical film-making, then "Open Water" is the movie for you.

reviewText: This movie is one of the SCARIEST movies I have seen in 52 years. The themes of isolation and unseen horror are floating along with the divers in this 81 minutes of HORROR. Anyone who did not think this was a horror movie is simply not as afraid of water as I am. Most horror films prey on being afraid of the dark. If you have only this juvenile fear, the night scene alone should scare the flippers off you. Contrary to what the other reviewers here would have you believe, there are quite a few scenes where there are sharks seen in the water, of fins gliding by in the distance, and of fins clashing together in close frame as two sharks dive out of and into the water so close together that their fins hit - IF you are paying attention, which some of the reviewers simply were not. The idea of a shark sliding by and zipping a leg off is terrifying. They can cut you in half at the middle so fast that you are still alive long enough to look down and see that half of your body is gone. That the divers feel fish biting at their legs or jelly fish are stinging them with like what feels like a fist hitting or they fall asleep and wake up alone or something hits them in the back and almost knocks them over, these things are so terrifying because they do not know what is happening under the water. That they are kept in constant fear can certainly sustain 81 minutes. Whether they are Great Barrier Reef sharks or Mako sharks or Great Whites, they all have something in common - rows of razor sharp teeth that keep on replacing themselves. I had a sense, the first time I saw it, that they would be saved, and that heightened my shock at the ending. I felt a sense of affrontery. The yellow camera, tethered to Daniel, was in view all through the film. It is marked on the IMBd website that the camera being pulled out of the shark's belly at the end is a piece of trivia! Far from a piece of trivia, this is one of the ways they found out who the divers were and what happened to them. (The other way was was the guy finding their diving certificates with their other belongings on the boat.) The shark was shown to eat the camera during the film; so how can it be mere trivia? I think people just do not want to admit how clever Chris Kentis was when he wrote the script and filmed the shark scenes. If you do not have the DVD, get it so that you can see the 'making of' video! Get it so that you can see the actors among REAL Great Barrier Reef Sharks. I guess that the negative reviewers do not want to admit how great this film is; I guess the landlubber film-goers just want to seem like they are above being afraid of sharks. One day, these negative reviewers should find themselves stranded - in open water.

reviewText: Open Water left me depressed. Not because it was a bad movie. It was an excellent movie. The depression was the result of the deliberate effect that the movie was intended to have.The idea was not to give the audience a flick that is thrilling, suspenseful or action packed. This is not an action flick. It's an exercise in tedium in a desperate, tedious situation. If your expectations are set for this prior to going in you will walk away with the correct experience.The two main characters (Blanchard Ryan and Daniel Travis) carry this movie superbly. You get to know them. You relate them. And you feel their despair as their plight plays out.Open Water captivates you into watching...not as an action flick or dramatic Hollywood production, but more as a documentary of the drama and actions of everyday people in a grinding, grueling experience.

reviewText: Open Water is a low-budget film.  This aides more than hinders the efforts of the filmmakers, ensuring that we do not recognize personalities so that we have no preconceived notions of the actors that are performing or the story that is unfolding.  The digital video gives it a documentary feel and everything that happens supports that.  The fact that the story is basically nonexistent also supports the films intentions.  We are privy to an extended period of the lives of two people we do not know, trapped in an impossible, and terrifying sitaution.  When the sharks are swimming around these people we perceive this as real (and it in fact is) and not some Hollywood robot.  The danger is always imminent, even when the sharks are unseen.The idea here is not to pull at your heartstrings, or to immerse in some deeply involved story.  It is solely to allow you to experience the primal horror of a situation that is conceivably plausable.  The actors are not famous because the filmmakers want us to know that it could be any one of us stuck in the water with the sharks, not Kevin Costner or Ashley Judd.  With personalities like that no one would ever believe that something bad would happen to them.  The actors, Blanchard Ryan and Travis Bickle (who acquit themselves admirably among the toughest of working conditions), allow the viewer to bob up and down in the water with them.Toward the end of the film, there is a scene that takes place during the night, after a bite, with the only light afforded to the couple coming from the random bolts of lightning crashing loudly as the sharks swarm.  This scene is among the most frightnening I have ever seen, and will not leave my memory anytime soon.If you enjoy squirming in your bed, or hunching yourself on the edge of the sofa, give Open Water a try, and then cancel your caribbean vacation when the credits roll.

reviewText: Yet another movie that was marketedly poorly and so received poor reviews from people expecting something different.This isn't Jaws.  It doesn't try to be and it shouldn't be compared to Jaws.  It involves sharks but the real fear, the real tenseness stems from not knowing what's around you.  The fear of the unknown is one of the biggest of mankind, as is evidenced in many many movies.  And, for me, there's nothing scarier than being trapped out at sea, slowly being pulled away from humanity and everything it stands for and finally not knowing what's around you.  It's a helpless situation.  What can you really do?  You can't drink the water, you can't swim toward land when land is not in sight.  No one sees you and oh did I mention there's a fin passing by you every so often?  For me, this movie had a knot in my stomache from the very first moment they realize they are stranded to the last shot.It doesn't have much action in it, true, but the feeling of being totally alone except for each other lends believability to their own internal dramas.  And that is, at the heart, what this movie is:  a drama.  Through all 79 minutes of the film, it is a detioriation of a married couple's lives.  They go through all the stages, bickering, acceptance, anger, fear, distrust, etc.  And, through their internal drama, we learn of their lives.  My one complaint for this approach is that I would have liked a little more time before them being stranded so I could get a better look at their life.As for the movie being based on a true story, it sort of is.  It's based on actual accounts of people being left at sea after going on diving expeditions.  This actually happens, not frequently, but the fact that it does happen is creepy enough to give me cause to pause.  I don't think I would ever go off shore diving after seeing this movie.Another interesting note that really doesn't serve much purpose to the plot of the film is that the actors were really in the water with real sharks.  On the first day of shooting, the female star actually was bitten by a barricuda.  It adds to the realism as you realize these aren't computer generated sharks they are worrying about like in Deep Blue Sea.  They are real.Overall, for me this was a pretty decent movie.  For those who like a lot of action, this is not a movie for you.  For those who want to see the next Jaws, this is not for you.  For those who want to feel that knot in their stomache and enjoy dramas, this is for you.

I realized after watching this that it is impossible to make floating in the ocean into compelling cinema.  I kept waiting for the movie to kick into high gear, but it never did. reviewText: After all the hype surrounding this film, I couldn't wait for it to come out on DVD at the local rental store, as I love a good shark flick and actually plan one of my summer vacation weeks around "Shark Week"on the Discovery Channel. I cannot believe there are such idiots out there in the world that are allowed to run a business (as in the boat charter), that have such a poor system of keeping track of their guests. The guy playing "Junior" must have had the mentality of a 2 year old. Perhaps the dude who played the obnoxious jerk on the boat threw off "Juniors" tracking skills with his annoying banter. Accidents happen, someone may tragically drown or get the "bends", but being left behind in shark infested waters is not just due to lack of good judgement. Now at least I am thinking, thank heavens these two will be found alive, probably scarred for live and in need of medical and psychological care, but still alive. Next night falls, and as dawn approaches it appears that Dan is no longer among the living as Sue still clings to his lifeless body. At this point I still have hope that she will be rescued and when the film ends as it does, I am left in absolute disbelief.To say this film was terrible is being too kind. I also played the director commentaries and after listening to the mindless drivel coming from Chris Kentis and his incredibly bland, boring, and overly enthusiastic wife (and assistant), it was no wonder why this films stunk so bad. I hope neither one paid good money for a higher education in film making as this film lacks professionalism. It's basically another scam with the likes of the other horror is is compared to, "Blair Witch Project", which was the first worst movie that I ever saw. This bomb wins the second worst. reviewText: Open Water is NOT a big budgeted Hollywood movie.  This is something that must be understood from the get go.  This is only director Chris Kentis' second feature film.  It was the first film for it's male lead Daniel Travis and the first starring role for female lead Blanchard Ryan.  Moreover the film has the look and feel of a documentary in the way it's filmed.  The sound is uneven in spots causing you to have to turn the volume up quite a bit higher than normal.  So these things must be understood because they are certain to put off people who are used to much more polished looking films.Susan and Daniel are a yuppie (is that still a valid term?) couple with hectic lives who take a rather rushed vacation to the caribbean.  While there they take a scuba diving trip along with several other people.  The organizers screw up the head count and when Daniel and Susan return to the surface they find that their boat has left them all alone in the middle of the ocean.  This certainly plays upon one of man's primal fears; the thought of being lost in the middle of nowhere.  To compound matters, sharks are swimming about and Susan has motion sickness from the choppy waters.After several hours on the water the pair begin a somewhat contrived argument over whose fault it is that they are in the situation.  It ends as quickly as it was thrown in however.  And it has the feel of a toss away plot device to add a bit of meat to the barebones plot.It's a short film and certainly doesn't end the way most people would think.  It's a rather voyeuristic character study as we glimpse at two people so wrapped up in their own lives that they don't realize they are both to blame.  The performances are strong and the style of direction and filming give it an edge that would be lost with a larger budget.  Not what I expected at all but still very good.

reviewText: First, let me say one thing.  If 'Open Water' had been released as small art-house film, I would have given it more than three stars.  The story about the two divers left in the middle of ocean is intriguing, and the film surely gives some very tense moments.  But I couldn't finally come to like it, and let me tell you the reasons as below.[TOO MUCH HYPE] What I really hate is not the film itself, but the way it was promoted.  At the beginning of the film they claim it is 'Based on the Real Events,' but the fact is, the film's script is mostly based on pure speculation about the real-life husband and wife who went missing mysteriously.  (I don't buy the idea that the scuba-diving people are so poor at counting the heads on the boat).But many films do the same thing, you might say.  Sure, but in addition to that, 'Open Water' tries to emulate 'Jaws,' which of course is not.  By repeatedly proclaiming that they 'used' real sharks, the film is desperately trying to lead us to think that the sharks would provide good thrills.  However, they simply don't because of the poorly-shot sequences, unexceptional dialogues, and not-so-good acting like three principals in 'Blair Witch Project.'  As to the sharks again, though the shark in 'Jaws' is obviously a fake, it had a real trained professional actors like Robert Shaw.If you still don't like my comments, how about this?  The film contains nudity (of the leading actress who bears her breasts in bed) while there is no need for that.  Why include nudity  when sharks would suffice to fill in the 79 minute film?  Why the unnecessary, very nasty end-credit sequences in which something is suggested?  To me, as I remember many 70s films, 'Open Water' looks like one of the exploitation films that appeared on the screen at that time.  'Open Water' is entertaining, and would be a nice choice if you watch it on DVD, but it does not deserve the box-office figures all around the world, or the accolades heaped on it by the critics.
summary: Fairly Entertaining, But Does Not Deserve the Hype

reviewText: I went to see OPEN WATER because a friend of mine told me that real sharks were used in the filming. When I went to the theatre I saw a tagline on the movie's poster that said something like "Based on a True Story." After seeing the movie, I chuckled to myself because I thought that tag line was part of the BLAIR WITCH type hype that was surrounding the movie. Later, I discovered that the tag line wasn't just a gimmick, because the movie really is based upon the true story of Tom and Eileen Lonergan who disappeared in a very similar fashion off the Great Barrior Reef in 1998.OPEN WATER is not a great movie, but it is a fairly good one. Considering the low budget and that the movie stars no big names whatsoever with a director that hardly anyone has ever heard of before, it's an extraordinary accomplishment. The acting in the film is very realistic and fits in with the grainy, home-movie feel. The editing and direction are also well done, e.g. the audience is given a break from the tension in the ocean with interspersed shots of the exotic locale that the movie's main characters, Daniel and Susan, were vacationing at. The sharks are kind of nice to look at too because they are real. In addition, the build up of the characterization between Daniel and Susan as they flounder deeper and deeper into the ocean works wonderfully.OPEN WATER's major flaw is that the film's conclusion is forgone before Daniel and Susan even leave their home. The movie is also only about 75 minutes in length. Therefore, there really isn't much movie here and it leaves the audience wondering "Is that all?"Still, everything the movie does get right balances out many of the negatives. It's better than THE BLAIR WITCH PROJECT, but not as good as JAWS.

reviewText: This film tries to marry the thrills of Jaws with the you-are-there documentary style of the Blair Witch Project. Unfortunately Open Water succeeds only in reminding you of how much better those two movies are in comparison.The first thing you'll notice is the photography, such as it were. It looks like it was filmed on the handicam your slightly drunk uncle waves around at family get togethers. I know full well this was done intentionally to achieve a "reality TV" type effect, but that doesn't change the fact that it looks and sounds like crap. Sure, the Blair Witch used video cameras and amateurish camera work, but it was rationalized within the framework of the story---we were supposed to be watching the footage shot by the characters themselves (and even then, the use of black and white, and the natural foreboding ambience of the woods provided some haunting imagery.) Open Water does not use the narrative gimmick of showing "actual footage" captured by the characters on their own cameras--its just inexplicably ugly and cheap. And if they were going for a "reality" vibe, why are there several instances of music added over the soundtrack?The acting and writing is weak. You never once  believe these are real people acting spontaneously...every line rings hollow. For the bulk of the film we are watching two characters, a husband and wife, floating in the sea, and the opportunity is certainly there for some dramatic soul bearing, but instead they just alternate between whining and smarm.Things start to pick up when night falls and we must rely on our ears while looking at a black screen (a similar "blackout" effect was used in the Blair Witch, and also older films such as Wait Until Dark and The Tingler). Unfortunately the scene is marred with poorly executed "lightning flashes", achieved by turning the image brightness up and down quickly. It looks fake and sabotages the one chance this film had to really lay on the scares.About the only positive thing I can say about Open Water is they used real divers in a real ocean with real sharks, which lends some much needed believability to this cheesefest. Of course if I want real sharks, I'll turn on Discovery Channel.If nothing else this film marks a new low in what is considered acceptable fare in mainstream movie theaters. I dread the day that this type of no-budget, no-talent, sensational dreck is the norm and carefully crafted, well written and well acted stories are the exception.
